entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:30:45+00:00 (#7593)

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:30:20+00:00 (#7591)
entry.content: Second - sort of simplistic root complex driver, you can learn reserved memory regions TOLUD, TOLUUD and stuff like that from pci device 0.0.0

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:30:16+00:00 (#7590)
entry.content: Is it still available once Windows is fully loaded?

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:29:32+00:00 (#7589)
entry.content: First way is to follow UEFI memory map. UEFI does everything for you

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:29:06+00:00 (#7588)
entry.content: I created this issue for further investigation: https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/issues/457

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:26:55+00:00 (#7587)
entry.content: As long as I remember, the arrangement of MMIO physical addresses only passes to Windows at startup (from UEFI).

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:26:38+00:00 (#7586)
entry.content: Yes, two ways

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:26:27+00:00 (#7585)
entry.content: That also means not 1 or 2 bytes. Only mov dword ptr

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:26:13+00:00 (#7584)
entry.content: One more question, is there any way to know whether and address is a RAM physical or an MMIO address?

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:25:23+00:00 (#7583)
entry.content: So, pci

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:25:16+00:00 (#7582)
entry.content: The mmio from the screenshot is a BAR address

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:24:50+00:00 (#7581)
entry.content: No, just 4 bytes. It‚Äôs by the PCI spec

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:24:26+00:00 (#7580)
entry.content: Not sure if I get it correctly. Reading 8 bytes at a time is not allowed?

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:23:20+00:00 (#7579)
entry.content: Your [memcpy] should only operate in aligned 4 bytes chunks there

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:22:48+00:00 (#7578)
entry.content: Once it‚Äôs random Realtek or something else, it will likely fail

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:22:20+00:00 (#7577)
entry.content: So they allow random width access

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:22:05+00:00 (#7576)
entry.content: It‚Äôs just Intel devices on bus 0 (root complex) are not real pci devices :)

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:21:43+00:00 (#7575)
entry.content: No, it should not by the PCI spec actually

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:21:30+00:00 (#7574)
entry.content: I see it‚Äôs Realtek

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:21:25+00:00 (#7573)
entry.content: 4 bytes? You mean reading 8 bytes from the MMIO space doesn't work? ü§®

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:21:22+00:00 (#7572)
entry.content: But non Intel - mostly not

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:21:12+00:00 (#7571)
entry.content: Intel devices allow that

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:21:05+00:00 (#7570)
entry.content: I observed a similar behaviour when I was using 64 bit implementation of memcpy

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:20:20+00:00 (#7569)
entry.content: Most likely one of those two things

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:20:03+00:00 (#7568)
entry.content: And accessed as 4 bytes. memcpy doesn‚Äôt work by default

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:19:41+00:00 (#7567)
entry.content: So it could be a caching problem?

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:19:11+00:00 (#7566)
entry.content: Ok understood your implementation, make sure it is mapped as uncached then

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:18:28+00:00 (#7565)
entry.content:
This function reserves a virtual address without actually allocating physical memory. Then, we could safely modify the PTE entry corresponding to this address and change the PFN of this address and access the physical memory using the same virtual address.
https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/blob/ceca0ae762b09ec9a8d55c94fcd62332e3657e04/hyperdbg/hyperhv/code/memory/MemoryMapper.c#L573

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:17:09+00:00 (#7564)
entry.content: Two points to consider when working with MMIO: EPT entry for that physical (system) address should be uncached. There are some devices that allow write-combined caching, but in general it is uncached. Second: it should be accessed as dwords (4 bytes)

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:15:16+00:00 (#7563)
entry.content: Sorry, don‚Äôt quite got what you mean. What is a reserved virtual address?

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:14:56+00:00 (#7562)
entry.content: Is it wrong? ü§®

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:14:27+00:00 (#7561)
entry.content: No, I think I mapped it to a reserved virtual address directly from PTE.

entry.title: @honorary_bot on 2024-08-18 11:12:34+00:00 (#7560)
entry.content: How do you implement physical memory access? mapiospace?

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:12:02+00:00 (#7559)
entry.content: HyperDbg cannot show MMIO addresses in the physical machine. I'll try to investigate that. ü§î

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-18 11:11:20+00:00 (#7558)

Have you tried accessing real MMIO addresses?

entry.title: @1906828983 on 2024-08-14 16:08:49+00:00 (#7546)
entry.content: I am discussing two issues: The first is to install hyperdbg on a real machine (using epthook), sleep and wake up the machine, and then send the exit command to exit and trigger a blue screen. The second is to install hyperdbg in vmware (using epthook) and then manually trigger sleep to immediately trigger a restart (no blue screen)

entry.title: @HyperDbgBot on 2024-08-14 16:02:46+00:00 (#7545)
entry.content: [discord] <rayanfam> [reply]: Also here is a video of debugging WinDbg by using HyperDbg, you might find it helpful: https://youtu.be/wL7qDdzq5gA?si=-r8T8aM7guyrr7Sd

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-14 16:00:57+00:00 (#7544)

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-14 15:58:55+00:00 (#7543)
entry.content:
There are a couple of ways for passing debugging events (e.g., #bp and #db) to the ring 0 or the ring 3 debuggers like using these commands:
test breakpoint off test trap off
You can use the above commands to pass events to x64dbg or WinDbg.

test NtOpenProcess test NtOpenProcess
the remote connection is closed
ffffffff: kHyperDbg>

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-11 06:24:09+00:00 (#7519)
entry.content: Though, you're callstack is really interesting to me, since it seems that a VMCALL vm-exit happens there which usually happens in the case of Hyper-V. As far as I know, VMware workstation won't use VMCALL instruction within the guest. So, just curious to know, is hyper-v active in your target system? ü§î

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-11 06:21:48+00:00 (#7518)

entry.title: @1906828983 on 2024-08-11 06:03:42+00:00 (#7516)
entry.content:
Has anyone encountered this error before? It is triggered when exiting debugging on a real machine (the computer was in sleep for more than 12 hours without being used before).
1: kd> k # Child-SP RetAddr Call Site 00 ffffab00`d17eb158 fffff806`608fbe2e nt!KeBugCheckEx 01 ffffab00`d17eb160 fffff806`6080891f nt!HvlpVtlCallExceptionHandler+0x22 02 ffffab00`d17eb1a0 fffff806`6075f917 nt!RtlpExecuteHandlerForException+0xf 03 ffffab00`d17eb1d0 fffff806`6075d846 nt!RtlDispatchException+0x297 04 ffffab00`d17eb8f0 fffff806`607fef42 nt!KiDispatchException+0x186 05 ffffab00`d17ebfb0 fffff806`607fef10 nt!KxExceptionDispatchOnExceptionStack+0x12 06 ffffa789`48c2f388 fffff806`608126e5 nt!KiExceptionDispatchOnExceptionStackContinue 07 ffffa789`48c2f390 fffff806`6080c178 nt!KiExceptionDispatch+0x125 08 ffffa789`48c2f570 fffff806`860a3fe2 nt!KiInvalidOpcodeFault+0x338 09 ffffa789`48c2f708 00000dcc`8167789f hprdbghv!AsmVmxVmcall+0x22 [f:\HyperDbg\hyperdbg\hprdbghv\code\assembly\AsmVmxOperation.asm @ 32] 0a ffffa789`48c2f710 00000000`00000000 0x00000dcc`8167789f

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 18:42:52+00:00 (#7512)
entry.content: You shouldn't use DbgPrint in hyperhv. You need to use the 'LogInfo' and its variants to use custom hyperdbg's logging component instead of DbgPrint.

entry.title: @yxxyz on 2024-08-10 18:41:20+00:00 (#7511)
entry.content: I add some log in hyperhv and it get this problem. If u want to reproduce this problem, you can try adding a breakpoint in vmm code.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 18:37:56+00:00 (#7510)
entry.content: How did you run HyperDbg? Is there a way I can reproduce your error?

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 18:37:23+00:00 (#7509)
entry.content: HyperDbg doesn't use DbgPrint and it's variants in the vmx root mode.

entry.title: @yxxyz on 2024-08-10 18:36:02+00:00 (#7508)
entry.content: it seems have connection with debugpoint and DbgPrintEx in vmm root when uses hostidt on nmi.

entry.title: @DK_ZAG on 2024-08-10 14:51:11+00:00 (#7507)
entry.content: üëå

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 14:49:50+00:00 (#7506)
entry.content:
HyperDbg, by its very design, is not intended for debugging games. Unlike traditional debuggers, it is more stealthy because it doesn't use any Windows debugging APIs. Debugging games are really complicated due to the anti-hypervisor and anti-debugging mechanisms they often use. This requires a deep understanding and advanced techniques to bypass these protections, which go beyond HyperDbg's intended use.
I see some individuals do modify HyperDbg for such purposes and keep those modifications private for their personal use, but please consider that HyperDbg's philosophy is to offer a powerful VT-based debugger with unique features that are not available in classic debuggers and it's not about facilitating game cheating.

entry.title: @DK_ZAG on 2024-08-10 14:36:02+00:00 (#7505)
entry.content: How to modify so that hyperdbg can debug games?

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 14:33:53+00:00 (#7504)
entry.content: Probably, the only currently maintained VT debugger is HyperDbg. I'm not aware of any other virtualization-based debugger that is currently maintained (working with the latest Windows versions).

entry.title: @DK_ZAG on 2024-08-10 14:28:48+00:00 (#7503)
entry.content: Is there any vt debugger source code that can debug games?

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 14:23:40+00:00 (#7502)
entry.content:
Did you try to change this pragma?
https://github.com/HyperDbg/HyperDbg/blob/ceca0ae762b09ec9a8d55c94fcd62332e3657e04/hyperdbg/hyperhv/code/vmm/vmx/VmxBroadcast.c#L31

entry.title: @yxxyz on 2024-08-10 14:07:18+00:00 (#7501)
entry.content: ü§£ my system stuck in vmware and i try to find the reason. it work if nmi used windows idt. if nmi use hostidt, windbg respon command extremely slow.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 13:45:11+00:00 (#7500)
entry.content: But it's kinda weird, why are you trying to do that? ü§î

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 13:44:34+00:00 (#7499)
entry.content: But, generally I think when an NMI is triggered, all other exceptions/faults/interrupts are masked until next execution of 'iret'.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 13:43:53+00:00 (#7498)
entry.content: Guest NMIs won't be handled like this, NMIs in guest are handled through a VM-exit.

entry.title: @HughEverett on 2024-08-10 13:43:04+00:00 (#7497)
entry.content: If you comment those lines, all exceptions are passed to the Windows IDT handler, except NMIs that are handled by HyperDbg.
